column1:
**CONTENT WARNING: THIS ARTICLE ADDRESSES TEENAGE SUICIDALITY**

If you or someone you know is in crisis::: you can call the National Suicide Prevention Hotline 24 hours a day: 1-800-273-8255. More resources available here: https://caps.byu.edu/community-resources

Researchers from BYU::: Johns Hopkins::: and Harvard have created an algorithm that can predict suicidal thoughts and behavior among teens with 91% accuracy. The team said the implications of the research are critical for prevention programming and policy making. Specifically::: they hope policymakers use the findings to prepare services::: resources::: and assessments aimed at school::: community and family settings.

This study identified three risk factors that are the leading predictors of suicidal thoughts and behavior among teenagers: being threatened or harassed through digital media; being picked on or bullied by a student at school; exposure or involvement in serious arguments and yelling at home.

‚ÄúClearly the results speak to the need for prevention and schools may be the best place to start by helping to mitigate bullying and online harassment:::" said study coauthor Carl Hanson::: professor of public health at BYU. "For communities::: we need programming that can help support and strengthen the family.‚Äù

Read the full article here:

https://news.byu.edu/intellect/byu-algorithm-accurately-predicts-when-teens-likely-to-have-suicidal-thoughts-behavior

NEWS.BYU.EDU
BYU algorithm accurately predicts when teens likely to have suicidal thoughts::: behavior
column3:
The algorithm doesn't sound that accurate. 91% accurate means that of 100 teens that it identifies as suicidal 9 actually aren't. And then of the 91 that are accurately diagnosed::: I'd assume a large portion of them are obviously struggling and this tool didn't add new information.

I would hate to have a parent or school counselor call me in to talk about my misdiagnosed suicidal thoughts. Potential users of this are going to forget very quickly that it has an error rate.

"I know you have been thinking about suicide. Tell me about it."

"No honestly Dad::: I'm really happy. Why do you ask?"

BYU researchers have made an incredible scientific discovery‚Äì‚Äìfor the first time in history::: humans have found earthly soil that appears uninhabitable::: even by the tiniest microscopic organisms.

‚ÄúA gram of soil has like a billion cells living in it::: but we couldn‚Äôt find a single cell in this soil:::‚Äù said BYU biologist Byron Adams::: who led the Antarctic expedition. ‚ÄúNo one has ever seen soil without microbes::: until now."

The Power of Positive Feedback:

A new BYU study found that when middle school teachers praised students...
‚Ä¢ Class-wide on-task behavior improved up to 70%
‚Ä¢ Students who were at risk for emotional/behavioral disorders saw grades improve by a full letter grade.

https://news.byu.edu/intellect/praising-middle-school-students-improves-on-task-behavior-by-up-to-70-byu-study-finds

NEWS.BYU.EDU
Praising middle school students improves on-task behavior by up to 70%::: BYU study finds
column3:
Of course - praise::: belonging::: acceptance::: love etc always help student's performance...O
h::: that is right::: I learned that at BYU 50 years ago.
column4: This is why I loved teaching middle school.
column5: Pay attention to good behavior.
column6: Really? A study found this out? You mean money was actually spent on a study to prove something that's been known since time immortal? I mean it was all in the song dont mess with mr in-between. As an educator of almost 30 years...its a no brainer. Yes you deal with the negative as it arrives::: but you always praise the positive and seldom have I seen it not generate positive outcomes. But that is also at any level of education. Just because you teach at a university doesn't mean you can become a cantankerous windbag or treat people like they've just discovered the letter A::: but you adapt the praise to the situation.

#EnterToLearnGoForthToServe BYU is a major partner in a new $14.6-million project to expand treatment and research on Alzheimer‚Äôs disease and dementia in American Indian::: Alaska Native::: Native Hawaiian and Pacific Islander groups.

Although these communities are culturally and geographically diverse::: they all experience an unequal burden of conditions such as hypertension::: type 2 diabetes and low socioeconomic status that make dementia more likely. In addition::: life expectancy is increasing for these groups::: and the number of older adults is climbing. There is growing concern that Alzheimer‚Äôs disease and related dementias may become a major public health crisis.
https://news.byu.edu/byu-major-partner-in-project-to-combat-alzheimers-dementia-in-native-pacific-islander-communities

column1:
BYU biology graduate student Natalie Saxton is part of a team of BYU biologists that has been tracking down dragonflies around the world::: from Vietnam to the islands of Vanuatu. Their goal is to piece together the first-ever phylogenic (genealogical) tree of all 6:::300 known dragonfly species and their ancestors.

Funded by the National Science Foundation::: the phylogenic tree will enable scientists to study how different species of dragonfly evolved over time through changes in characteristics like vision and flight::: which may in turn illuminate how other animals speciate.

Both the novelty and the usefulness of the work has been thrilling for the scientists.

‚ÄúYou kind of feel like one of your biology heroes:::‚Äù said Saxton::: ‚Äúgoing out into the wilderness at the edge of the world to find new species.‚Äù

Read more about the research here: https://news.byu.edu/intellect/byu-biologists-travel-the-world-to-chart-over-6-300-dragonfly-species

column1:
Immigrant communities such as a Jewish settlement in Clarion and a Thai community in Layton may not be as well-known or remembered but still play an important part of Utah‚Äôs history ‚Äî a history rich with diverse stories of faith and perseverance. With the passage of time::: however::: many of the stories of Utah‚Äôs immigrants are on the verge of being lost.

BYU history professor and Associate Director of the BYU Redd Center::: Brenden W. Rensink::: hopes to change that through a new website and mobile app called Intermountain Histories ‚Äî a platform dedicated to highlighting significant places and people who helped shape the history of the Intermountain West. The project is managed and edited by Rensink while students from multiple regional universities contribute individual stories.

"Too often we stop with the most obvious histories::: or the histories that we grew up hearing::: and we never pause to ask::: ‚ÄòWhat else is out there?‚Äô‚Äù Rensink states. ‚ÄúThere are infinitely more perspectives::: voices and stories that we haven‚Äôt heard than ones we have::: and you don‚Äôt have to dig very far to find them.‚Äù

Read more and explore Intermountain Histories here: https://news.byu.edu/intellect/byu-professor-highlights-unsung-stories-from-utahs-rich-pioneer-history-with-intermountain-histories-website

NEWS.BYU.EDU
BYU professor highlights unsung stories from Utah‚Äôs rich pioneer history with Intermountain Histories website

This list represents just a sampling of the goods and services advertised to Utah frontier women in the Woman‚Äôs Exponent::: the preeminent woman‚Äôs newspaper published in Salt Lake City from 1872 to 1914 to share local and general news::: household tips and educational materials. Thanks to an ongoing project by the BYU Office of Digital Humanities and the Harold B. Lee Library::: anyone can now explore life in nineteenth-century Utah through a new searchable::: browsable database of the newspaper‚Äôs ads.

Read more about this project here: https://news.byu.edu/intellect/curious-about-utahs-frontier-women-browse-byus-new-database-of-womens-newspaper-ads

column1:
As social media and other online networking sites have grown in usage::: so too has trolling - an internet practice in which users intentionally seek to draw others into pointless and::: at times::: uncivil conversations.

New BYU research sheds light on the motives and personality characteristics of internet trolls. This research found that individuals who experienced pleasures from the failings or shortcomings of others considered trolling to be acceptable online behavior. Because of this view::: they're not concerned with how their words or actions affect those on the other side of the screen.

BYU communication professor and co-author of this study::: Dr. Pamela Brubaker said::: "As we connect with people online::: we should strive to be more respectful of others and other points of view. [...] Each of us has the power to be an influence for good online."

Read the full story: https://news.byu.edu/intellect/whats-in-a-troll-byu-research-examines-motives-of-internet-trolling
column3: So in other words::: if someone is goading you into making an emotional response::: do not engage. Because for them::: that is positive reinforcement to continue their behavior. I also think that there is some confusion on the definition of "trolling:::" I wish the video had talked about that before delving into the outcomes of their research.
column4: Trolling is not pointless. If executed properly::: its purpose is to satirize and expose foolish views in front of an online audience.
column5:
Um::: who gets to decide what constitutes pointless conversations::: Pamela? I know that's a base you and yours would love to steal::: calling all those who disagree with you trolls. Unfortunately::: I think we'll deny you that right.

Trolling is characterized by the state of mind of the troller::: not the trollee. If the person making a contradictory argument has no desire to have a true exchange of ideas but rather::: gets his or her jollies from winding up others::: then you have a troller. Your discussion of Dark Triad::: which is actually a tired::: unhelpful::: faddish "diagnosis:::" might have some merit.

If the person making a contradictory comment is truly intending to contend with a tough::: controversial topic::: you do NOT have a troll. You have someone who disagrees with you::: whose opposition and arguments cannot be blithely dismissed. Certainly::: you CAN dismiss that opposition . . . with better arguments.
column6: It doesn't matter how stupid or illogical the things you say are::: we should defend the right for you to say them. Freedom of speech.

column1:
It's official‚Äì‚Äìfall semester 2021 will be a traditional semester with the majority of courses offered in-person with full-capacity classrooms.

Fall semester 2021 will operate like a traditional fall semester due to the downward trend in COVID-19 infections and increased number of vaccinations within the campus community.

BYU will also be evaluating how virtual learning may have improved some elements of courses and curricula and hopes to incorporate the best of those changes as it prepares for a more traditional fall semester.

Masks and physical distancing will not be required during fall semester. This decision is subject to change depending on trends in disease prevalence and guidance from state and local governments. Individuals may choose to wear a mask in any setting.

Get more details here: https://news.byu.edu/announcements/byu-will-hold-traditional-fall-semester-in-2021

NEWS.BYU.EDU
BYU will hold traditional fall semester in 2021

How often have you laid in bed scrolling through news stories::: social media or responding to a text? After staring at the screen::: have you ever found that it is harder to fall asleep?

It‚Äôs widely believed that the emitted blue light from phones disrupts melatonin secretion and sleep cycles. To reduce this blue light emission and the strain on eyes::: most smartphones now have some sort of night mode function that claims to help users sleep better.

Until recently::: claims of better sleep due to Night Shift have been theoretical. However::: a new study from BYU published in "Sleep Health" challenges the premise made by phone manufacturers and found that the Night Shift functionality does not actually improve sleep.

Read the whole story here: https://news.byu.edu/intellect/is-night-shift-really-helping-you-sleep-better

Is Night Shift really helping you sleep better?

For BYU Ph.D. graduate Steve Bates::: the popular tune ‚ÄúHome on the Range‚Äù hits close to home. Since 1999::: Bates has worked as the wildlife manager at Antelope Island State Park in Utah::: and he knows a thing or two about the land ‚Äúwhere the buffalo roam.‚Äù He‚Äôs accustomed to the dazzling sunrises and picturesque settings the island offers ‚Äì and he‚Äôs dedicated much of his life to researching::: preserving and protecting the wildlife living there.

Bates‚Äô passion for wildlife stretches back to his childhood years::: where he fondly recalls spending summers living in the mountains and working with his father::: the game manager for Utah‚Äôs Division of Wildlife Resources.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs where I developed a love for the outdoors and for all creatures:::‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI knew then that I wanted to be a wildlife biologist.‚Äù

Read the full story about this April 2021 graduate here: https://news.byu.edu/character/phd-graduate-shares-his-passion-for-the-outdoors-with-the-next-generation-of-students

Now a successful fourth-year business Ph.D. student at the University of Michigan::: BYU alumna Hilary Hendricks can remember earlier days when‚Äîhaving moved her family across the country to attend a top program‚Äîshe felt herself unequal to the challenges of doctoral study. What kept her going were her mentors from her previous time as a BYU MBA student.

‚ÄúI‚Äôd be walking across campus in Ann Arbor thinking::: ‚ÄòThere‚Äôs just no way I can do this.‚Äô But then ... I would recite to myself all of the professors at BYU who helped me to get where I was:::" says Hendricks.

The excellent preparation Hendricks received for graduate school is reflected in data from the National Science Foundation::: which shows that BYU prepares more future Ph.D. students in both business management and foreign languages than any other university in the United States. The data also shows that BYU graduates have outsized success completing doctoral programs in a host of other areas::: including chemical engineering::: education research::: mechanical engineering and psychology.

BYU has long been recognized as a top school for preparing future doctoral students::: ranking sixth in the nation for the number of students who go on to earn doctoral degrees::: according to the federally sponsored Survey of Earned Doctorates. From 2009 to 2018::: 3:::040 former BYU students completed a Ph.D.::: an average of about 300 per year.

Read the full story here: https://news.byu.edu/byu-no-1-in-the-nation-for-launching-business-foreign-language-ph-d-s

NEWS.BYU.EDU
BYU No. 1 in the nation for launching business::: foreign language Ph.D.s

Spencer Larsen::: a BYU senior who serves as one of four vice presidents in the BYU Student Service Association::: said that this semester‚Äîone of the most unique in the school's history‚Äîhas been the most fulfilling of his academic career. This is all due to a new initiative that morphed the BYUSA office into a production facility focusing entirely on making and delivering COVID care packages to fellow BYU students.

The idea came from BYU freshman Emily Seals::: a volunteer with BYUSA::: who herself was experiencing the isolation of quarantine early in the semester. She contacted Larsen::: expressing the need to help their peers who were in similar situations. Seals created an online survey that allowed BYU students who were experiencing isolation to virtually connect with other students and request a care package to be delivered to their doorstep. So far::: over 800 care packages have been delivered to students in various situations and new requests continue to come in.

column204:
Borrowed

Truth
3 years from now::: some of you will look back & admit that you spent an entire year of your life wearing a mask::: cooped up in your house & avoiding all the people you love. üò≠ A year in your life that you‚Äôll never get back.
Every single day is a risk.
Car accident::: flu::: etc.
Our days were numbered from the moment we took our first breath. Life isn‚Äôt a race where we win against the inevitable! That has not changed since the beginning of time!
BUT::: we should not be forced to live in fear.
We went from being a free nation to being told we:
üö´ couldn‚Äôt go to school
üö´ couldn‚Äôt go to church
üö´ couldn‚Äôt go to our grandma's house
üö´ couldn‚Äôt pay respects to a loved one through a funeral
üö´ couldn‚Äôt leave our homes
...and when we were allowed to do these things::: we were told:
üì¢ how long we could be there
üì¢ how far apart we have to be
üì¢ which direction to walk
üì¢ what to wear
üì¢ what we can buy/not buy
üì¢ where we could shop/not shop
üì¢ whether we could sing/worship/
take communion
üì¢ what time we had to be home
Yes::: our health matters.
But you know what else matters?
‚úÖ Family.
‚úÖ Friends.
‚úÖ Church.
‚úÖ School.
‚úÖ Sporting events.
‚úÖ Family vacations.
‚úÖ Neighborhood BBQs.
‚úÖ Life.
‚úÖ Fitness.
‚úÖ Hugs.
‚úÖ visiting the hospitalized
Etc..etc...
üíî One day::: you‚Äôll hug your grandma::: mom::: dad::: or brother for the last time.
üíî One day::: your best friend will cry on your shoulder for the last time.
üíî One day::: your child will play their last hockey game.
üíî One day::: they‚Äôll have their last day of school.
üíî One day::: you‚Äôll spend your last day laughing with a loved one.
üíî One day::: you‚Äôll dance your last dance.
Don‚Äôt waste the days you have by living in fear.
Your time here on earth matters.
Live your life while you have the chance.
God is gonna call you home when it‚Äôs your time.
Virus or no virus.

column1:
The cooking sessions in BYU professor Marie Orton‚Äôs Italian 361 class represent her passion for helping students to connect‚Äîwith each other::: with her::: with the subject matter. Orton said her teaching methods are inspired partly by the examples of many colleagues in the unique language programs at BYU::: which offers its students immersive course experiences in 63 languages and which ranks third in the nation for the most bachelor degrees in a foreign language.

Orton‚Äôs fall class investigated what makes Italians ‚ÄúItalian‚Äù: how history::: politics::: sports::: fashion::: music::: literature and (of course) food create a common identity among a people who unified from a loose group of nation-states less than two hundred years ago.

Teaching a typically in-person experience‚Äîcooking as a class‚Äîinto a virtual experience is no small feat::: but Professor Orton believes it has kept the Italian mentality of cooking food together intact.

‚ÄúIn Italy::: food and group identity are inseparable:::‚Äù she explained. ‚ÄúEverybody who goes there realizes very fast::: food is about anticipating and preparing::: cooking with other people::: letting a sauce boil down for six hours and talking about it as you eat it. It‚Äôs all about what we‚Äôre doing together.‚Äù

‚ÄúOne thing that I‚Äôve loved about Professor Orton‚Äôs class is that she is really good at bringing us close to the things that we‚Äôre learning about:::‚Äù said BYU senior Emma Stucki. ‚ÄúTechnology can be a barrier sometimes::: but it was lovely to share Italian food culture as a class.‚Äù

column1:
In accordance with Utah State Public Health Order 2020-27 and the Utah System of Higher Education COVID-19 Intensive Testing Plan::: Brigham Young University students 18 years or older who live in on-campus housing or attend at least one in-person or blended class are asked to take a COVID-19 screening test during the first ten days of winter semester. These students may also be invited to participate in focused and random testing throughout the semester if selected to do so.

Similar to the voluntary testing in November and December::: BYU will be administering these COVID-19 screening tests free of charge to students who are not experiencing any symptoms and haven‚Äôt tested positive in the last 90 days.

Entry testing will run Jan. 8‚Äì20 (excluding Sundays and the Martin Luther King Jr. holiday) in the Wilkinson Student Center Garden Court and in the Richards Building. Register for a testing time at byu.edu/coronavirus/student-covid-19-testing.

If you are experiencing symptoms within this testing period::: you can receive a test at the BYU Student Health Center which will be covered by your insurance or by BYU.

In addition to this initial entry testing::: BYU will continue to require face masks and use of the Healthy Together Passport app (or the digital or physical daily passport forms) in order to access certain on-campus services and facilities::: including the Harold B. Lee Library and devotionals and forums. These rules apply even if you‚Äôve already had COVID-19.

Thank you for helping to make BYU and its surrounding community a safer place to live and learn this winter semester. Your efforts will help keep our campus open.

@BYU I am literally astounded. I just read through the link you provided that you are using rapid antigen tests. Those have an INCREDIBLY great risk of false positives. This is directly from the FDA website:

"For example::: a test with 98% specificity would have a PPV of just over 80% in a population with 10% prevalence::: meaning 20 out of 100 positive results would be false positives.The same test would only have a PPV of approximately 30% in a population with 1% prevalence::: meaning 70 out of 100 positive results would be false positives. This means that::: in a population with 1% prevalence::: only 30% of individuals with positive test results actually have the disease.At 0.1% prevalence::: the PPV would only be 4%::: meaning that 96 out of 100 positive results would be false positives."

column1:
Utah Governor Gary Herbert declared a state of emergency and issued an executive order on November 8. In addition to other statewide restrictions and requirements::: the executive order requires weekly COVID-19 testing for college students who either live on campus or attend at least one in-person class per week. Each university campus is required to have a testing process in place by January 1::: 2021.

In an effort to rapidly implement large-scale COVID-19 screening testing for students on campus::: BYU has adopted the following three-part plan for the remainder of fall semester:

1. BYU will begin student COVID-19 screening tests November 18 through November 21.

2. COVID-19 screening tests are only for current students who are not experiencing symptoms of COVID-19 and have not tested positive for COVID-19 within the last 90 days. Students who are experiencing any symptoms of COVID-19 should get tested at the BYU Student Health Center or through another healthcare provider.

3. BYU non-student employees will not be part of the COVID-19 screening tests. Faculty and staff who wish to be tested can visit coronavirus.utah.gov for information on state testing locations.

Current BYU students may volunteer to participate in these screening tests. This information will give you the opportunity to make compassionate decisions that are best for yourself::: your family::: and your friends during the Thanksgiving holiday.

Testing will take place in the Wilkinson Student Center Garden Court this Wednesday through Saturday (Nov 18‚Äì21) by appointment only. These screening tests are a "short-swab" nasal test::: brushing 1 inch into your nostril. Test results will be available shortly after each test is administered.

After January 1::: 2021::: this testing will be mandatory for students living in on-campus housing and students taking at least one in-person class.

Thank you for your continued efforts to protect yourself::: your loved ones::: and our BYU community.

For more information or to sign up for an appointment::: please visit https://www.byu.edu/coronavirus/student-covid-19-testing

BYU.EDU
Student COVID-19 Testing

column27:
From Yale Epidemiologist:::
Jonathan Smith: An important Covid Message

"As an infectious disease epidemiologist:::
at this point I feel morally obligated to provide some information on what we are seeing from a transmission dynamic perspective and how they apply to the social distancing measures.

Like any good scientist I have noticed two things that are either not being articulated or not present in the ‚Äúliterature‚Äù of social media.
I have also relied on my much smarter infectious disease epidemiologist friends for peer review of this post; any edits are from that peer review.

"Specifically::: I want to make two aspects of these measures very clear and unambiguous.

"First::: we are in the beginning of this epidemic‚Äôs trajectory. That means even with these distancing measures we will see cases and deaths continue to rise globally::: nationally::: and in our own communities in the coming weeks.

This may lead some people to think that the social distancing measures are not working. They are. They may feel futile. They aren‚Äôt. You will feel discouraged. You should. This is normal in chaos.

But this is normal epidemic trajectory. Stay calm. This enemy that we are facing is very good at what it does; we are not failing. We need everyone to hold the line as the epidemic inevitably gets worse.

"This is not my opinion; this is the unforgiving math of epidemics for which I and my colleagues have dedicated our lives to understanding with great nuance::: and this disease is no exception.

I want to help the community brace for this impact. Stay strong and with solidarity knowing with absolute certainty that what you are doing is saving lives::: even as people begin getting sick and dying. You may feel like giving in.

Don‚Äôt.

"Second::: although social distancing measures have been (at least temporarily) well-received::: there is an obvious-but-ove
rlooked phenomenon when considering groups (i.e. families) in transmission dynamics.

While social distancing decreases contact with members of society::: it typically increases your contacts with family members /very close friends.

This small and obvious fact has surprisingly profound implications on disease transmission dynamics.

Study after study demonstrates that even if there is only a little bit of connection between groups (i.e. social dinners::: playdates/
playgrounds::: etc.)::: the epidemic isn‚Äôt much different than if there was no measure in place.

The same underlying fundamentals of disease transmission apply::: and the result is that the community is left with all of the social and economic disruption but very little public health benefit.

"You should perceive your entire family to function as a single individual unit; if one person puts themselves at risk::: everyone in the unit is at risk. Seemingly small social chains get large and complex with alarming geometric speed.

If your son visits his girlfriend::: and you later sneak over for coffee with a neighbor::: your neighbor is now connected to the infected office worker that your son‚Äôs girlfriend‚Äôs mother shook hands with. This sounds silly::: it‚Äôs not. This is not a joke or a hypothetical.

We as epidemiologists
see it borne out in the data time and time again and no one listens. Conversely::: any break in that chain breaks disease transmission along that whole chain.

"In contrast to hand-washing and other personal measures::: social distancing measures are not about individuals::: they are about societies working in unison.
These measures also take a long time to see the results. It is hard (even for me) to conceptualize how on a population level::: ‚Äòone quick little get together‚Äô can undermine the entire framework of a public health intervention::: but it does.

I promise you it does. I promise. I promise. I promise.

"You can‚Äôt cheat it. People are already itching to cheat on the social distancing precautions just a ‚Äúlittle‚Äù- a playdate::: a haircut::: or picking up a needless item at the store::: etc.

From a transmission dynamics standpoint::: this very quickly recreates a highly connected social network that undermines all of the work the community has done so far.

"Until we get a viable vaccine this unprecedented outbreak will not be overcome in one grand::: sweeping gesture::: rather only by the collection of individual choices our community makes in the coming months.

This virus is unforgiving to choices outside the rules.

"My goal in writing this is to prevent communities from getting ‚Äòsucker-punched
‚Äô by what the epidemiological
community knows will happen in the coming weeks.

It will be easy to be drawn to the idea that what we are doing isn‚Äôt working and become paralyzed by fear::: or to just 'cheat‚Äô a little bit in the coming weeks.

By knowing what to expect::: and knowing the importance of maintaining these measures ::: my hope is to encourage continued community spirit::: strategizing::: and action to persevere in this time of uncertainty."

-\-\Jonathan Smith:::
Epidemiology of Microbial Diseases and Global Health
(Lecturer)
Yale University School of Public Health
(Whose research focuses on
infectious disease transmission dynamics)

column1:
The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints
27 October 2020 –≥.::: 10:12 ¬∑

‚ÄúToday at Brigham Young University I shared a message about important issues of our day::: including overcoming racism. Personal attitudes and official practices of racism are not consistent with the revealed word of God. We know that God created all mortals and we are all children of God. The challenge of racism is not a new one::: but recent events have precipitated the current discussion.

‚ÄúThe shocking police-produced death of George Floyd in Minnesota last May was surely a trigger for nationwide protests in the United States::: whose momentum was carried forward under the message of ‚ÄòBlack Lives Matter.‚Äô Of course Black lives matter! That is an eternal truth all reasonable people should support.

‚ÄúDear friends::: let us all heed President Russell M. Nelson's call to repent::: to change::: and to improve. Only the gospel of Jesus Christ can unite and bring peace to people of all races and nationalities. We who believe in that gospel‚Äîwhatever our origins‚Äîmust unite in love of each other and of our Savior::: Jesus Christ.‚Äù ‚ÄîPresident Dallin H. Oaks

Read full address here: https://bit.ly/34vQrBi

Artwork: used with permission from the artist Amber Eldredge
column3: To Heavenly Father and hopefully to all of us... every life matters.
column4: I don‚Äôt like that Oaks commented on the Floyd death when there is no verdict yet and it may very likely be not police brutality at all! This goes against everything were taught about obeying laws of the land which states innocent until proven guilty! Also what is alarming is to hear him assume racism is a big problem right now when it statistically is not! When the church denied blacks priesthood there was racism but he didn‚Äôt remind us of the church‚Äôs mistakes with this in the past which was far more harmful! He also must not realize that mask wearing is a state issue and not a federal mandate! My state does not require masks::: yet the church has not respected my states law that allows mask wearing at church! The church has asked all states abide by the church mandate::: infringing on individual states rights! Sadly::: Oaks is out of touch and living in a bubble!
column5: Today while I was in the check out line at Target::: there was a little black girl in front of me. She was so cute and precious! She made my day! There is beauty all around us::: if we just stop::: look and listen.
column6:
In my ward::: I am the Relief Society president. For me and members of my diverse ward::: the BLM movement has been about asking tough questions about who gets heard::: about who is made uncomfortable or made to feel other when they come to church or activities::: about who gets callings. It has led to productive conversations and real steps forward. Our stake president has been asking the tough questions as well. We are learning to ask and listen. The civil rights movement took us some distance::: but there is progress to be made.

The BLM movement is about creating that change from wherever we are. I believe that we all need to do that work. I think of the scripture::: "Wo be unto him that is at ease in Zion. Wo be unto him that crieth: All is well." If we want to be like Jesus::: we have some soul searching to do. By looking for things we disagree with in the BLM movement::: we can miss the point-\-\sort of looking for the mote in someone else's eye when we have a beam in ours. Concerning ourselves only with rioting destruction::: is misguided. That destruction::: I believe::: can grow out of a sense of powerlessness and rage that comes from not being heard. I want to be one of the listeners. Destruction needs to stop::: but I'm not going to be the one tasked with tending to that. Consequently::: I don't want it to stop me from from paying attention to the things I can actually do something about.
column7:
If the title is so misleading why does President Oaks have it on his personal page. How dumb are people in the first place::: that they think that everyone who says::: ‚ÄúBlack Lives Matter‚Äù are ONLY those who align with the organization that bears the same name? Why is it so darn hard to understand that we are referring to the sentiment and not an organization???
? Why does this ALWAYS need to be clarified??? Why? Because people with racism and racial bias can‚Äôt get with it. Point. Blank. Periodt.
column8:
You have to read the whole article to really understand that he is not endorsing blm. He is reminding us that the only way to really come together is to come closer to Christ. As His representative:::
he will always teach that.
column9: Comment threads are such a revealing gauge of what people want to hear and what they've chosen to retain. Taking a close listen to President Oaks' remarks takes us away from the fringes and reactionary mindsets in which many of us have taken refuge::: and allows us to see that the 'sides' of our man-made culture war offer little of worth in the face of what the gospel of Jesus Christ offers us and instructs us to create - unity::: community::: equality::: family. Zion. He and others offered this counsel at our October General Conference. It's so disheartening to see to what lengths we will go to reject the words of our prophets. On the other hand::: having the dialogue::: challenging ourselves and each other to work past the ideas we have previously held is part of the process of conversion. Here's to those who are willing to take those steps.

column1:
A shortage of N95 masks worldwide has led to important developments on campus with the Nanos Foundation. Undergraduate students from BYU's Sensors and Applied Biomechanics Engineering Laboratories helped develop a way to turn a regular cloth mask into an N95 mask.

Using a process called electrospinning::: student researchers create membranes comprised of trillions of nanofibers that trap particles‚Äîincluding viruses. These nanofiber membranes within a regular cloth mask provide the same filtration as an N95 mask.
column3:
"When Should a Mask Be Used?

Face masks should be used only by individuals who have symptoms of a respiratory infection such as coughing::: sneezing::: or::: in some cases::: fever. Face masks should also be worn by health care workers::: by individuals who are taking care of or are in close contact with people who have respiratory infections::: or otherwise as directed by a doctor. Face masks should not be worn by healthy individuals to protect themselves from acquiring respiratory infection because there is no evidence to suggest that face masks worn by healthy individuals are effective in preventing people from becoming ill."

column1:
Catastrophic fires in the West are burning hotter than ever::: leaving paths of destruction through both human development and native plant ecosystems.

Using seed enhancement technology never before used in rangeland restoration::: BYU professor of plant and wildlife sciences Matt Madsen and his students are leading an effort to reseed fire-scorched landscapes across the Great Basin with native plants. This technology includes seed coatings traditionally used in commercial farming (for food products) and other treatments that are specifically formulated for rangeland seeds.

How it works and which coating is used depends on the seed::: but the goal is always the same: help the seeds get distributed evenly into the soil and give them the best chance for survival.

NEWS.BYU.EDU
Fighting fire with seeds: BYU helps native plants survive

column1:
In response to recent COVID-19 trends in our county::: the following joint letter was sent this morning to all BYU and UVU students from President Worthen and President Tuminez:

Dear Students:::

As the presidents of the two largest universities in the state of Utah::: we are grateful that we have been able to open our student facilities and offer face-to-face classes this fall semester. We thank those who have been compliant with the safety guidelines that have been put in place due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

However::: we are greatly concerned about the dramatic rise in positive cases of COVID-19 in Utah County::: particularly among college students. This is both alarming and unacceptable.

We‚Äôre concerned not only for your well-being::: but also those in the local community who are affected by the trends we‚Äôve seen in the last week.

Behavior must change. We implore you to stay home except for in-person classes::: work::: church::: and other essentials. We ask that you limit your social interactions to only those within your household and avoid small gatherings where individuals aren‚Äôt wearing masks or maintaining physical distance. If you‚Äôre feeling sick::: stay home. If you've had a known exposure to the virus::: may test positive for the virus or are awaiting a test result::: follow the quarantine guidelines of state and local health officials. We expect you to follow all safety requirements on campus and all state and local mandates off campus.

If circumstances do not improve within the next two weeks::: more dramatic action will be necessary. This may include a two-week quarantine::: closing campuses to the public or a complete retreat to all-remote instruction for the rest of the semester.

Please be wise. Your individual choices will make all the difference.

Sincerely:::

Kevin J Worthen::: BYU President
Astrid S. Tuminez::: UVU President
column3: Faith over fear! What happened to living by gospel principles? BYU has sold out long ago. Yuck.
column4: I'm surprised at how many people get all ruffled by something as simple as this. They're just asking the students to help out in this situation. I am shocked at this statement. It is so condemning and full of blame. Germs are not going away. Colds are not going away. This statement blames college students for coughs and colds. There has been and will be coughs and colds and sickness and death. Staying home for part of the day or putting on a mask will not stop colds not viruses from affecting humans. This year nor next year nor the next year::: bacteria and viruses will still affect humans by causing sickness especially to weakened immune systems. Telling the young people to get more sleep::: eat more fruits and vegetables::: drink more water::: and to eat much less junk food would have a better affect on their health than telling them to isolate themselves and create more loneliness and fear.

Please please don‚Äôt blame the students for coughs and colds and fall viruses. Let‚Äôs support them in healthy socializing and normal social living. No blame only truth in science and in health.

column96: My son tested positive for Covid last week. He has firmly adhered to guidelines and doesn‚Äôt know where he picked it up from. His 3 room mates who weren‚Äôt as strict about wearing masks and not gathering all tested negative. The biggest issue is that BYU doesn‚Äôt have a firm plan in place and isn‚Äôt responding quickly enough to what is happening. My son was finally isolated 24 hours after his test came back::: and it took another 50 plus hours after that for his case worker to finally contact him. Luckily::: he had already texted everyone that he had had been into contact. Some people chose to get tested and others didn‚Äôt. He can only pass along the information. The other issue I see is just how difficult going into isolation is. These kids often feel sick and are placed in a situation in which they are entirely alone. It was stressful figuring out meals and how best to support him from afar. I think this needs to be better handled. My son felt a complete lack of compassion and I felt that he had been totally left alone and that he had no one checking in on him (until he received a call from his case worker 3 days later) and this is unacceptable. I understand that they are adults::: but I also believe that BYU has a responsibility try to take care of them. I worry that this may be preventing kids from being tested who probably should be. Without testing we can‚Äôt monitor or understand the way this virus is working.

Dear University Presidents:::
Why?
You have a community of humans who are in their healthiest years::: who live amongst peers instead of at home with older family members::: who are best suited to recover from this virus in a week‚Äôs time without being in ICU or on a Ventilator::: who are attending Universities to be a part of an enriching community as much as expanding their education::: who frankly are already donating plasma on the regular and now can help more susceptible populations in Utah with their convalescent plasma. How many of these sick students in this rising trend are in intensive care? How many are dealing with debilitating long term effects? The few years a student spends at BYU or UVU are fleeting but formative! Never again will these students have so many cultural and social resources at their disposal and the ability in their lives to partake. Never again will they have the perfect set of life circumstances that allow a building of peer to peer relationships::: relationships that can last a lifetime. The ends here do not seem to justify the means.

column239:
I agree with Oxford's head of Evidence Based Medicine::: Prof. Carl Heneghan::: lockdowns are not the answer and we have to learn to live with this. It's never going to be eradicated. Spanish Flu hits us every year. It never left. These viruses never really appeared. They just jumped species. Imagine if regular influenza had not made the jump to humans until 2020 and we suddenly had 50:::000 excess deaths. We'd be locking down. But hindsight tells us we can live with it::: and viruses resulting in higher deaths because they're more contagious::: not because they're more intrinsically fatal. The scientists at schools like Oxford and Imperial College preached herd immunity from the beginning. They ultimately gave into the political backlash because people are uncomfortable with the idea::: and it will cost politicians their jobs. These same scientists are still saying we need the younger population to be exposed to this::: as a long term approach::: not a short term bandaid which lockdown is. We can't live in fear. This meme was making the rounds back in March::: but we seem to have forgotten - Per CS Lewis:::

In one way we think a great deal too much of the atomic bomb. ‚ÄúHow are we to live in an atomic age?‚Äù I am tempted to reply: ‚ÄúWhy::: as you would have lived in the sixteenth century when the plague visited London almost every year::: or as you would have lived in a Viking age when raiders from Scandinavia might land and cut your throat any night; or indeed::: as you are already living in an age of cancer::: an age of syphilis::: an age of paralysis::: an age of air raids::: an age of railway accidents::: an age of motor accidents.‚Äù

In other words::: do not let us begin by exaggerating the novelty of our situation. Believe me::: dear sir or madam::: you and all whom you love were already sentenced to death before the atomic bomb was invented: and quite a high percentage of us were going to die in unpleasant ways. We had::: indeed::: one very great advantage over our ancestors‚Äîanest
hetics; but we have that still. It is perfectly ridiculous to go about whimpering and drawing long faces because the scientists have added one more chance of painful and premature death to a world which already bristled with such chances and in which death itself was not a chance at all::: but a certainty.

This is the first point to be made: and the first action to be taken is to pull ourselves together. If we are all going to be destroyed by an atomic bomb::: let that bomb when it comes find us doing sensible and human things‚Äîpraying:::
working::: teaching::: reading::: listening to music::: bathing the children::: playing tennis::: chatting to our friends over a pint and a game of darts‚Äînot huddled together like frightened sheep and thinking about bombs. They may break our bodies (a microbe can do that) but they need not dominate our minds.

‚Äî ‚ÄúOn Living in an Atomic Age‚Äù (1948)

The relatively small amount of human suffering and death that come from this virus are not reduced by austere enforcements::: it's just dragged out over months (and years?)

Those at extreme risk (nursing home residents and staff::: chemo patients::: ect) should be the only ones quarantining (and they should be very strick about it).

All others::: especially young healthy college students::: should be living their lives and building the population's herd immunity. This is nature's vaccine if you will. A developed vaccine is going to take a while.

Look at Sweden: they did it right and they've had no 'second wave' like the US and elsewhere in europe. It's nearly over for them and their communities are intact.

Also::: even if on-campus students do their best::: you've got 6 or so students living together::: and each spends time with a different circle of classmates and co-workers. That is a recipe for virus spread even with masks. Regardless::: social interaction is important for humans. No need to be hard on students.

'2 weeks' became 'a few months'::: and will that become 'a few years'? You would never swear off driving because of the risk of death... Because you assess the benefits of transportation to be greater than the cost. We need to seriously reassess what an appropriate response looks like.

We have forgone the benefits of timely treatment for other medical issues::: quality education - especially for children::: healthy local economies with local businesses - in effect your neighbor's livelihood::: social interaction important for mental health::: ect. This will bring some decline in quality of life::: and some poverty::: which are predictors of shorter lifespans. Human life years are very possibly being lost::: but no one considers this as the effects are well-distribute
d.

A primitive insect-like creature that has survived 30 ice ages was recently rediscovered in Antarctica by a team of scientists who had been searching for it for decades.

Researchers::: led in part by BYU‚Äôs Byron Adams::: are using the history of the tiny little microscopic Antarctic animals to solidify exactly how ice sheet dynamics played out over time and how they impacted historical ecosystems.

‚ÄúBiology can be a powerful tool for making inferences about earth history:::‚Äù said Adams::: who has traveled to the Ross Ice Shelf in Antarctica every year for the past 17 years to collect samples. ‚ÄúWe were thrilled to see the evolutionary history of the organisms is consistent with current models and geological and glaciological estimates of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet dynamics.‚Äù

As the 2020 U.S. elections approach and the pandemic persists::: many states are considering a mandatory vote-by-mail system as a safe alternative to in-person voting. But policymakers are fiercely divided: Will vote-by-mail favor the Democrats::: mobilizing left-leaning voters who ordinarily avoid or miss the polls?

According to a new BYU study::: probably not.

Published in the journal Science Advances::: the research looked at voting patterns in areas that have historically implemented vote-by-mail for federal elections. The BYU professor and his co-author found that while vote-by-mail did increase overall voter turnout by about 2 to 3 percentage points::: it did not change the outcome of races.

‚ÄúWe ran dozens of analyses and every single time we found no impact in partisan vote shares. So whether you‚Äôre advocating for vote-by-mail because you think it‚Äôs going to be really good for your party or advocating against it because you think it‚Äôs going to be bad for your party::: you‚Äôre probably wasting your time:::‚Äù said Michael Barber::: a BYU professor and co-author of the study.

https://news.byu.edu/forty-years-of-voting-history-reveals-vote-by-mail-does-not-give-either-party-an-edge

You sort of missed the point::: BYU.

The point of concern isn't whether or not simply "vote by mail" gives one party an "edge" over the other. I don't think anyone believes that if the vote is by mail::: that more people in one party will vote than the other. There's no reason for anyone to believe::: nor have I heard anyone say::: that one party uses the USPS more often than another::: or will refuse to vote if it's by mail. (Unless Green Party people refuse to do vote by mail because it uses more paper and kills more trees and they all decide not to vote? Somehow I doubt that.)

The issue is whether or not vote by mail makes it easier to commit voter FRAUD. Obviously::: there is a need for people to be able to vote by mail. Some people just can't get out to do it. But the concern is that the MORE vote-by-mail there is::: the more FRAUD there will be. A quick look at the CONVICTIONS of voter fraud cases shows that a LOT of them were committed THROUGH mail in::: absentee voting and creating false registrations for mail-in voting. And all jurisdictions KNOW that.

There have already been several instances::: just in the past couple months. People have been getting ballots for people who USED to live at their address. One woman had 4 ballots for 4 different people sent to her. Another woman noticed that the bar code on the envelopes included an "R" on hers::: and a "D" on her brother's::: and the city VERIFIED that the codes include R and D for party affiliation. There are more instances all over the country.

The other issue is the "why". Why "mandatory" mail in voting? It's very difficult to believe that the why is truly for Covid safety concerns::: when restaurants are open::: schools are open::: grocery stores are open::: and heaven knows::: the protestors and rioters are free to roam the streets with no social distancing being enforced. The ONLY reason to make it mandatory::: would be to allow more fraud to occur.

column1:
Today marks the beginning of a unique New Student Orientation for this unique school year.

President Worthen had this message to share with this year‚Äôs freshmen class::: which includes important reminders for us all.

A large-scale project from BYU professors and students is gathering lost stories of a generation that survived extreme hardships under the Khmer Rouge regime (1975-79) where nearly 2 million Cambodians were killed or died.

As a community that relies on oral and not written histories::: many of the stories of past Cambodian generations are being lost.

Known as the Cambodian Oral History Project::: the group from BYU has collected nearly 5:::000 interviews for this project through the help of local Cambodian leaders.

Telling their stories can help the Cambodian people heal in a small way from the devastation they faced years ago::: helping family members understand who their parents and grandparents are and also who they are.

NEWS.BYU.EDU
Cambodian Oral History Project

column15: ‚ÄúThere is no greater agony than bearing an untold story inside you.‚Äù Maya Angelou. Telling an untold story from inside you remains the best therapy for PTSD clients in particular the KR‚Äôs survivors. I‚Äôm one of those who‚Äôd narrowly escaped this holocaust. For over 30 years living in a third country::: I‚Äôd tried hard to erase the scar of this bloody past::: but I can‚Äôt. The more I‚Äôd tried to forgive::: the more I can‚Äôt forget. Everyday::: I‚Äôd tried to run away from the bloody past::: the past caught up on me faster and stronger. It was like running away from a mountain. The faster you run::: the closer and bigger the mountain appears behind you. But I‚Äôd tried all::: working two jobs::: burring myself in schoolwork::: involving in community activities::: never talking about the past::: etc. Not a single effort had worked. The scar of the past is too deep to erase. I still slept with nightmares. I still saw the tyrants with guns and cleavers chasing after me in my dream. I decided to walk straight back to my past. That was six years ago. I was tired living and walking with a bagful of the tragic past on my back. Somehow::: it wasn‚Äôt easy::: especially when I went back to an unknown graveyard where a man told me that he had buried my two beautiful children who‚Äôd perished one after another from prolonged starvation. The dark memory returned so fresh::: so vivid that I felt decimated::: hopeless. I sobbed. My family of nine who‚Äôd walked and crawled together along Highway 5 during the evacuation day in April 1975::: only three had survived the Pol-Pot‚Äôs barbaric regime. Each of us has story to tell. Yours could be more painful than of mine. But ours could be less tragic than of our friends next door. Come out and tell your story. Of course we can‚Äôt rewind the 3 year and 8 months life struggles in one sentence::: but let the people know about you. Let the world know about the almost forgotten Khmer Rouge‚Äôs tyranny. Because the more you know of yourself::: the better you become liberated. Thank you BYU for this unique page.

Smith have found that our relationships impact our physical health so profoundly that chronic loneliness and isolation can be as dangerous as a pack-a-day smoking habit. BYU Vocal Point director McKay Crockett has the recipe for magic: get a group of singers together::: add a room with great acoustics::: and you‚Äôll start hearing notes that aren‚Äôt being sung. These are harmonic overtones::: and they are often the element of music that brings chills.

Special thanks to BYU Singers alumni for helping with this video from BYU Magazine.

A new analysis of 115+ studies on the effectiveness of masks in controlling COVID-19 has gotten a lot of attention with stories from the Deseret News::: The Salt Lake Tribune::: KUER 90.1 and others today.

The analysis has also gone viral on Twitter and is spreading throughout Instagram via a spotlight in our story that just published.

What prompted the report: BYU professor Ben Abbott seeing a lengthy debate about masks::: where else::: but right here on Facebook. üôÇ (Details in the KUER story we've linked to.)

The comprehensive analysis by Dr. Abbott and three of his students provides important insight and context about mask wearing amid this global pandemic. Overall::: the researchers conclude from the research that:

"Masks could be one of the most powerful and cost-effective tools to stop COVID-19 and accelerate the economic recovery."

Within the studies::: the researchers found that masks are highly safe::: with only minor and uncommon side effects. In addition to many medical studies::: public masking has been proven safe among children::: adults and the elderly.

"There is now convincing evidence from multiple controlled experiments and field observations that wearing masks reduces the transmission of COVID-19 for healthcare workers and the public. Most of this evidence is COVID-19 specific and has emerged in the past few months."

Read the full analysis:

https://pws.byu.edu/covid-19-and-masks

KUER.ORG
BYU Researcher Says The Science Is Crystal Clear: Wear A Mask

column4:
My opinion about this study has to do with the study itself and has nothing to do with my thoughts on mask wearing.

As a scientist myself::: I have two major problems with this report. One is that there is no original research in this report. It is a study of studies::: which I have no way to verify any of the methods used or data collected. I cannot simply accept a conclusion or what someone tells me the study says. In general::: I will totally ignore studies with no original research for this reason.
Two::: this is outside of the area of expertise of everyone involved. While there are some things that translate between scientific disciplines::: there are many things that don't. Being a scientist of any sort generally qualifies you to read and have an understanding of any report::: but does not qualify you to publish your conclusion.

I am sure they had good intentions. But::: I cannot (and really we should not) accept their conclusions.

column11: Hi. My husband was one of the students who worked on this paper. First::: they received zero funding from BYU to do this research. There was absolutely no agenda. Second::: they looked at ALL of the data. Over 115 studies! They did not pick and choose studies that supported a certain ideology. They looked at all of the evidence::: explored all of the science::: and broke it down so the average person could understand it. Please::: just open the paper. You‚Äôll see how much work they put it and how in depth they went. You‚Äôll see that all of their sources are credible and peer reviewed. They did this out of their own time and free will because they wanted to explore the evidence (both pros and cons) of wearing masks. The evidence was overwhelming. Please don‚Äôt assume everything you read online is true. Don‚Äôt disregard the 115+ credible sources for the one you found online. Read the evidence yourself and form an educated opinion before you blindly attack those just trying to get to the bottom of this issue.

A placebo at best. Those blue surgical masks seem to be the other most common mask. They are also virtually useless too. Why? They are made to be used in a sterile environment::: like an operating room...a room where there are no tiny virus floating around. The blue mask is made to reduce things that are roughly 200x bigger like bacteria from the human mouth. Also::: they have virtually no seal face to mask. The topic of droplets and aerosols came up. Here too the masks do very little. You can make a small case that if you cough::: droplets are suppressed. Droplets fall to the ground quickly::: so that is not really the issue. What about aerosol? Like I said::: no cloth or surgical mask is stopping a tiny virus size particle. If you are talking N95 or N100::: they can make a difference. But reality shows that no one in any quantity has those. And face shields are really needed with them to do the best job. With the virus having a 99.65% survival rate anyhow::: wearing a mask is not going to make a difference. Personally::: I wear one to make others "feel" better::: but it does little. Wash your hands::: stay apart (no riots & looting please). That will help more that a mask in the outdoors. No??
column124:
So::: is the goal again to slow the spread so that the availability of health care resources is not overwhelmed? Because the only end to this pandemic is innoculation::: either by infection and recovery or a vaccine. Run-and-hide isn't gonna get us to the other side of this.

There are a few references in the meta-analysis that suggest that masking is intended to "stop the spread" and a lot of the media messaging continues to imply (brow-beat::: more like) that masking will help us end this faster. That's not going to happen. We'll just rubber band from a low infection rate to a high infection rate until enough people have the antibodies that this is effectively over. The theoretical ideal::: given the lack of a safe and effective and widely available vaccine::: is for the virus to spread as quickly as possible without overwhelming hospitals and with special precautions to isolate high-risk individuals.

If we need to mask up in order to manage the availability of health care resources without unnecessarily dragging this out::: then great. So far::: that hasn't been the case and::: as has been pointed out::: the politicos and media have burned up what little credibility they had left when they kept shifting the goalposts to keep people scared when their initial apocalyptic forecast of 2M people dying fell completely flat. Classic "boy who cried wolf" scenario.

I got the cringes from Goldman Sachs's analysis that masking would prevent "the need for a second round of economic shutdowns". The available data analysis on that demonstrated that there was no statistically significant correlation between the severity of economic lockdowns and the spread of COVID-19 (offhand::: I recall that the p-value was in the neighborhood of .35). Anybody suggesting this route again should be immediately dismissed and discredited.

I appreciate the honest effort to show what's out there in the medical literature::: but it's difficult to trust what anyone is saying. The politicization of the issue was its downfall from the beginning.

A central question DeSantis posed to each was whether another statewide lockdown should no longer be an option. The three experts agreed that another lockdown would cause more damage than good.
Bhattacharya answered DeSantis by saying another lockdown in Florida ‚Äúwould be disastrous.‚Äù

Kulldorff said elected officials should be doing as much as possible to protect the elderly while still allowing children and young adults to go about life normally::: albeit with more frequent hand-washing.
‚ÄúThese sort of general lockdowns for closing schools::: for closing restaurants::: for closing beaches or whatever::: that actually has a detrimental effect on public health ...‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe are protecting very low-risk college students and professionals who can work from home while we are putting all the working-class people at risk because they have to work.‚Äù

Kulldorff said universities should operate ‚Äúalmost normally‚Äù and that students should be on campus attending in-person classes and that there does not need to be testing at colleges and universities.
People are still locking down and engaging in behavior which is likely to be detrimental in the long run:::‚Äù Levitt said.

Moisture retention::: reuse of cloth masks and poor filtration may result in increased risk of infection. Further research is needed to inform the widespread use of cloth masks globally. However::: as a precautionary measure::: cloth masks should not be recommended for HCWs::: particularly in high-risk situations::: and guidelines need to be updated.‚Äù

In the United States::: girls represent only about 20% of autism diagnoses. While boys may simply be more likely to have autism than girls::: mental health professionals suspect that girls are also more adroit at suppressing autistic traits::: which could prevent their autism from being diagnosed::: if it is diagnosed at all::: until they are adults. Without an autism diagnosis::: any mental health concerns these women experience may be misinterpreted.

New BYU research draws attention to the challenges such women face. The study showed a strong correlation between how much women with autistic traits camouflage‚Äîhide or compensate for autistic qualities to fit in‚Äîand the severity of their mental health concerns.

NEWS.BYU.EDU
Women ‚Äúcamouflaging‚Äù autistic traits suffer severe mental health challenges::: BYU study finds

column1:
We‚Äôre announcing today plans for an in-person fall semester. This decision is subject to change depending on trends in disease prevalence and guidance from state and local governments.

The following are the general plans::: and we will keep detailed updates coming as fall semester draws near.

- Fall semester will start August 31 with a hybrid of in-person and remote delivery.
- Fall semester classes and exams will be remote after Thanksgiving break. If you travel home for Thanksgiving::: you‚Äôll be encouraged to finish the semester there.
- Face coverings will be required in all classroom settings::: inside all university buildings::: during interactions with campus guests or customers and in other areas where directed.
- Priority registration for fall semester will begin July 6. You‚Äôll be notified via YMessage of your specific registration date. Class schedules and the registration cart with be available later this afternoon.
- There will be a phased return to campus for students in on-campus housing.

The safety and protection of the BYU community is BYU‚Äôs first priority. BYU students in high-risk categories::: including older adults and those who are immunocompromised::: are strongly encouraged to not be on campus during fall semester 2020. Additionally::: those who will be caring for or sharing living spaces with high-risk individuals are encouraged to not be on campus during fall semester 2020. Remote coursework options are available for students in these situations. Students will have the ability during class registration to choose from those courses designated as ‚Äúlive remote delivery‚Äù and "on-demand remote delivery." High-risk students can contact their advisement centers or call (801) 422-4104 for registration assistance.

From President Worthen:

‚ÄúFor this to succeed::: we all have to play our part. The BYU mission statement says that all relationships within the BYU community should reflect ‚Äòa loving::: genuine concern for the welfare of our neighbor.‚Äô Certainly that can be our motivation for wearing a face covering::: washing our hands often::: and staying home when we're sick. We can react with empathy when someone we know tests positive for COVID-19. We can fight the virus of contempt with kindness even as we debate how to best respond as a society to the pandemic.

That genuine love for each other is what will make this year's BYU experience a remarkable period of growth for each one of us. We look forward to safely gathering soon.‚Äù

BYU.EDU
BYU COVID-19 Updates

column23:
As an at-risk incoming master's student who will be teaching in the Fall::: I am disappointed in this announcement:

1. There is no indication of what options teachers will have::: esp. someone like myself who won't even have the protections of being a full-time employee:::
2. Provo's inadequate housing supply leaves landlords in a powerful position vis-a-vis students::: even when factoring in decreased demand. In particular::: the 'leave after Thanksgiving provision' is guaranteed to cause landlord-tenant
conflict:::
3. As a teacher::: mixing online and in-person is a mess logistically but::: more particularly::: is inevitably unequal. Students who feel compelled to attend online are necessarily disadvantaged compared to their in-person peers::: which is only aggravated by departments' insistence that grades follow predetermined distributions:::
4. The fact that this is all subject to change means that we cannot reasonably rely or plan based on this announcement. This will also lead to landlord-tenant
issues and losses related either to reliance or nonreliance::: however this pans out. In short::: the uncertainty of the whole situation is barely improved.

column1:
At the request of President Kevin J Worthen and under the direction of Academic Vice President Shane Reese::: last week a committee was appointed to examine issues of race and inequality at BYU and provide recommendations to the university about specific actions to address these issues. The committee will meet for the first time this week.

The committee will first prioritize opportunities to better listen to::: and better understand::: the experiences of black students::: faculty and staff on campus to help inform adjustments and changes that can assist BYU in being a more safe and welcoming place for BYU‚Äôs community members of color.

The committee takes seriously the charge issued by President Russell M. Nelson and leaders of the NAACP:

‚ÄúWe likewise call on government::: business::: and educational leaders at every level to review processes::: laws::: and organizational attitudes regarding racism and root them out once and for all. It is past time for every one of us to elevate our conversations above divisive and polarizing rhetoric. Treating others with respect matters. Treating each other as sons and daughters of God matters.‚Äù

Along with President Nelson‚Äôs encouragement on social media to:

- Foster our faith in the Fatherhood of God and the brotherhood of man.
- Foster a fundamental respect for the human dignity of every human soul::: regardless of their color::: creed or cause.
- Work tirelessly to build bridges of understanding rather than creating walls of segregation.

The newly-appointed committee members are:

Moises Aguirre::: Multicultural Student Services
Ryan Gabriel::: Department of Sociology
Lita Little Giddins::: College of Family::: Home::: and Social Science
Vern Heperi::: Office of Student Success and Inclusion
Carl Hernandez III::: J. Reuben Clark Law School
Jon McBride::: University Communications
Stephani Perkins::: Athletics ‚Äì Women‚Äôs Track
Shane Reese::: Academic Vice President‚Äôs Office

Beyond this committee::: many other members of our BYU community will be utilized in assisting in this work. Of particular importance will be the voice of BYU students.

The committee is eager to get started::: and will immediately commence its work by reaching out to many students and members of the BYU community::: ready to listen.
column3: One final thought as stakeholders move forward: let's consider what it means to "care"-\-\why do we "care about" these issues related to race and inequality? Are we simply responding to external pressures? Do we care enough to be bold in our actions? And pressing forward::: how do we show that we "care for" one another as members of the body of Christ?

column15:
BYU GREAT START FOR CHANGE!

I am not one to post strong opinions on social media like this. Nevertheless::: I felt a very strong need to do so as it is something that is so near and dear to my heart. I would::: however::: like to preface this by saying that it is not my intention to tarnish the name of BYU in any way::: because I am in fact a very proud graduate of Brigham Young University.

Believe me::: there are many great lessons and experiences that BYU and the people that I met here brought into my life. However::: there is an undeniable::: unfortunate truth that accompanied me throughout my time at BYU and that is a constant feeling of inadequacy rooted in my not being part of the majority (i.e.::: a Caucasian student).

Looking back::: I should‚Äôve been more involved in BYUSA and activities::: but I wasn‚Äôt. Why? Because I never felt I belonged or that my opinion would be valued the same as that of my Caucasian peers. The truth is there is strength in numbers. Assuming that BYUSA membership is an accurate representation of the ethnic demographics of the university::: that would mean my opinion as a minority student would be 81% more likely to be outvoted by my peers.

I think that multicultural student should be encouraged to take part in student body leadership. How::: you may ask? By demonstrating and fostering a welcoming atmosphere towards other cultures::: backgrounds::: opinions::: experiences::: and languages.

I propose two small actionable items that can demonstrate additional desire for change:

1. Move the BYU Multicultural and International offices #outofthebasemen
t floor and unto the same level as BYUSA. This will help prevent multicultural students from feeling they are not on the same level as their Caucasian peers.

2. Have BYUSA promote and engage in the multicultural activities organized by Multicultural Student Service and International Service Offices. (Once::: I asked if I could leave some flyers for a Multicultural Student Services event::: a university sponsored event::: an event supported by the Dean::: and I was told NO::: because they only promoted BYUSA events.)

Riddle me this: are we not on the same team? are we not on the same level?

Let‚Äôs continue towards Becoming One.

column39: A large portion of non-white students at BYU are international students::: who often come from low-income families in developing countries and who struggle financially through college at a much::: much higher rate than their American counterparts. And at least while I was there::: BYU's attitude towards us was very unhelpful. For example: the vast majority of financial aid was based on your GPA::: as if students who have to work to put themselves through college can really compete for grades against students who get all their expenses paid for by their parents. So a good first step would be to recognize that BYU should have more income-based financial aid::: especially for international students who cannot apply for US government grants and loans. If you are serious about decreasing racial inequality::: put your money where your mouth is.

COVID-19 has posed serious issues for doctors and nurses assessing patients' hearts and lungs with stethoscopes. To protect patients and practitioners::: BYU College of Nursing and BYU College of Engineering professors designed a digital stethoscope that makes it possible to assess patients while standing up to 50 ft away. The sytem costs less than $20 to make with 3D-printed parts and the professors have made the open source plans available to all.

column1:
A message from President Worthen:

With the tragic deaths of George Floyd::: Breonna Taylor::: Ahmaud Arbery and others over the years::: and the confluence of recent events::: important conversations are happening throughout the nation::: including at BYU.

We extend our love and concern to all members of our university community who are impacted by these events.

We know there is work to do::: on campus and throughout the nation::: for us to better come together::: to address injustice and to truly love one another. It will take sustained effort from all of us to make things better. We remain committed to doing that. We can do that in a unique way at BYU because of our understanding of the important truth that each of us are children of heavenly parents.

BYU stands firmly against racism and violence in any form and is committed to promoting a culture of safety::: kindness::: respect and love.

As we continue to move forward together::: let us do so with charity. Let us be kind. Let us respect others. Let us listen. Let us follow the example of Jesus Christ.

column15:
I suppose if the motto of BYU is ‚ÄúEnter to Learn. Go forth to serve.‚Äù::: we know that likely many of our graduates will move throughout the nation and the world. We will meet upon a variety of God‚Äôs children. You may look at it and think you have nothing to contribute today::: but I am sure many of us will be touched by future intolerance in various communities. Even things that will never make the news.

I left Provo and found myself teaching in a school in Kentucky where I was the minority in the room for the first time in my life. I had to recognize my biases to do my job well and to truly be a Christian. And decades later::: even just this week::: I recognize I could have definitely done it better. But when we know better::: we do better. I wish I would have known more then. Denying that I had any racism in my heart just because I thought I treated everyone fairly was pretty naive::: I now recognize.

If we truly recognize the power of the graduates of this institution and our power for good wherever we go::: recognizing what we can do in our sphere to decrease racism should be part of that education.

Understanding others' perspectives and having empathy for them is needed now more than ever. This specific issue of race equality and police work is complex but really important. We can simultaneously be grateful for the many good officers and be vocal about a tragic pattern of prejudice that is seen in current and historical data.
I have empathy for::: I benefit from::: and I appreciate the sacrifices police officers make. They see a lot of traumatizing stuff on the job. That takes a toll. They deserve the space and training to process that. And they need to recognize the humanity of every individual they encounter in public and learn from the data and history or it's time to move out of the public service into another line of work.
My hope is that our elected officials work together to improve policing and take better care of officers too. Partisan bickering isn't going to get us far.

Sometimes::: having the right balance of restrictions provides us with the most freedom.

This pandemic is practically harmless to children::: flu-level threat to teens and young adults::: and only a major issue for the elderly::: the smokers::: and the generally immuno compromised.

It‚Äôs no skin off my (young adult) teeth to wash my hands an extra few seconds::: stand away from others::: and not help the elderly get a large jug of salsa off the top shelf at the grocery store.
The high risk group::: and those living/

location.

It‚Äôs not a loss of freedom to let cars and school kids cross at a 4-way stop sign instead of charging through::: or to come to a full stop even when the intersection is clear. It shouldn‚Äôt be a loss of freedom to act defensively as the quarantine loosens its restrictions.

I‚Äôm trying to do some research using only open sources. Has BYU done any studies to determine the true risk of asymptomatic transmission of any respiratory virus?

I recently found a few studies claiming they monitored asymptomatic cases. However::: they only used nasal swabs. That is only a screening test that confirms exposure but not necessarily infection. It definitely didn‚Äôt confirm that viruses were being emitted.

I‚Äôm looking for a study that captured the breathing of asymptomatic subjects and analyzed how many viral particles were emitted.

Miss Sloan::: if you are truly concerned about liberty::: trust that there are things afoot in the world that will help you and others lose your liberties.
Mask wearing MAY help in some cases of extreme exposure and confined spaces. However::: the garden variety masks we see daily are not adequate for anything but the most rudimentary tasks::: and not worth the paper they are made of.
Perhaps the larger concern here is behavior modification::: like Pavlov's dogs. Combine this with draconian measures to isolate the "non sick" and scare them daily with lies and false reporting::: and WE become the ones being conditioned. Conditioned for control. For manipulation. For subjects of those who would exercise unrighteous dominion.
We are alive today because our Wonderful Creator designed us to be adaptive and self maintaining.
I chose to go bare footed::: drink from a garden hose::: ride in the back of pickup trucks::: eat apples right from the tree::: tomatoes from the garden::: share a soda pop::: pet a doggie or three::: swim in a creek::: eat candy i found under the car seat::: and on and on.....
You are welcome to your opinions. As our we. I chose to try to maintain what I can these days by what has served me for decades. I chose not to wear a mask.
