New 2020 The Wall Street Journal ranking: BYU is No. 1Ô∏è‚É£ in the west::: and No. 4Ô∏è‚É£ in the nation::: for student engagement. üéâ

To address the first 10 or so comments we typically see when talking about this metric::: this ranking is NOT about engagements to be married. We fully understand BYU would be at the top of such a ranking as well. Feel free to still make your engagement-related joke in the comment section::: if you'd like::: but the reality of this ranking is actually pretty important and valuable as you look at what it means for the holistic BYU experience.

For the WSJ's purposes in this ranking::: "student engagement" is defined as how connected students feel to their school::: each other and the outside world.

So ‚Ä¶ in a time when we‚Äôre all more physically-separated than ever::: we‚Äôre fortunate to still be a part of a BYU community where individuals feel much more connected than most.

From President Worthen:

‚ÄúYou students have the rare opportunity to be part of ‚Ä¶ a compact society that God has prepared to help you learn and develop Christlike attributes. You are not here by accident. You have been gathered here by God. Whatever your background::: whatever your talents::: whatever your challenges or perceived weaknesses::: you are a vital part of this gathering. You have something to gain from and something to offer in your interactions with those around you.

May each of you recognize and delight in the blessings of being fully engaged in this unique kind of gathering ‚Äòof learners and lifters‚Äô is my prayer.‚Äù

WSJ.COM
Top Colleges in the West for Student Engagement

Actually::: politics - and the vigorous and immediate weaponization of COVID by the Ruling Class (in Andrew Codevilla's sense) and applied with sharp focus by scores of governors and mayors across America (with vital assistance from a now utterly corrupt and intellectually vacuous media) was what turned our lives upside down::: destroyed the economy::: ruined tens of millions of livelihoods (and lives) and at least a hundreds thousand small businesses::: and tore at the very fabric of our constitutional liberties and unalienable rights::: riddling us with fear::: paranoia and a year and a half of mass hypochondria (for a middling virus not unlike many others of the same kind::: or the yearly flu).

COVID killed half a million people (perhaps half that when all the false attributions are filtered out down the road)::: virtually all of which were the same people who are killed each and every year by the garden variety flu::: and which was substantially exacerbated by the lockdowns::: mass quarantining (especially of nursing homes and assisted living facilities etc.) and short-circuitin
g of natural herd immunity.

Let's get this straight: COVID did not "turn our lives upside down;" that was accomplished by the mainstream media::: politicians and bureaucrats at the state::: municipal and federal levels. COVID is a very real virus::: actually dangerous only to a tiny few. The massive dislocations of American life were the work of human beings and political policy.

column47:
COVID - 19 turns one's life upside down because they allow it to. Just like BYU mandating masks. The data is very clear when it comes to the ineffectiveness
of cloth and surgical masks. Many studies were done during the height of the pandemic that supposedly proved they worked. The problem with these studies is that none of them were conducted under conditions of a randomized controlled trial::: which has been recognized by scientists & physicians for 50+ years as the gold standard of scientific testing. In these trials::: researchers recruit people and split them into evenly matched groups. They offer one group a certain treatment and another group no treatment. This way when they test for the outcome they have a control group to measure against.

Pre-Covid::: a total of ten "gold standard"::: randomized controlled tests were done for medical masks. All of them came to the same conclusion... they don't work::: unless you are wearing an N95 mask::: sealed & fitted to your beardless face::: and only then if the wearer is trained on how to use it. All of these studies showed very low effective rates for surgical masks and next to zero effectiveness for cloth masks. You can see the data and the summary of these 10 studies here: https://
wwwnc.cdc.gov/
eid/article/26/
5/
19-0994_article. The medical and science community did not see the need to invest further research funding into doing subsequent tests from that point forward because the results were so conclusive.

Post Covid::: only one randomized controlled test has been conducted on masks (to my knowledge) and was conducted specifically to examine whether masks protected their wearers from the Coronavirus. It was a study out of Denmark published in November of 2020. The results were the same as previous tests::: in that mask wearing "did not reduce::: at conventional levels of statistical significance::: the incidence of Sars-Cov-2 infection". See that study here: https://
www.acpjournals.
org/doi/
10.7326/M20-6817.

To this day::: even the World Health Organization says the evidence of mask efficacy is underwhelming: https://
www.who.int/
publications/i/
item/
advice-on-the-us
e-of-masks-in-t
he-community-du
ring-home-care-
and-in-healthca
re-settings-in-
the-context-of-
the-novel-coron
avirus-(2019-nc
ov)-outbreak

Unless future::: large randomized controlled trials find different results::: the Danish mask study::: matched with its predecessors::: essentially should end the debate of whether surgical masks protect people who wear them outside hospitals (much less cloth masks). As physicians and infectious disease professionals largely agreed until April of 2020 (suspiciously):::
the answer is THAT THEY DON'T WORK. Anyone who says otherwise::: for whatever reason::: is ignorant::: too lazy to research the truth on their own (or both)::: caving to social pressure::: or purposely being untruthful.

A group of BYU students designed a 10-day Positivity Challenge to help combat the loneliness & anxiety of COVID-19 ‚¨áÔ∏è

Day 1: Leave sticky notes with nice messages on someone's door
Day 2: Write a gratitude note to a coworker::: mentor
Day 3: Call someone to check on them::: catch up
Day 4: Share inspiring/uplifting material on social media
Day 5: Make a meal/treat to share
Day 6: Pay for someone's meal in a drive-thru; Venmo a friend and say "lunch is on me"
Day 7: Make kind comments on someone's social posts
Day 8: Share a funny meme or joke with someone
Day 9: Get up and move; Go on a walk and wave to people you pass or do yoga with friends over FaceTime
Day 10: Encourage others to spread positivity by sharing these ideas

DESERET.COM
The COVID-19 10-day positivity challenge

What happens when women are outnumbered? After years spent analyzing lab and real-life settings to determine what it takes for a woman to really be heard‚Äîto truly be perceived as competent and influential‚Äîa trio of BYU professors have found the same truth: for women::: having a seat at the table does not mean having a voice.

‚ÄúWomen are systematically seen as less authoritative:::‚Äù says BYU Political Science Jessica Preece. ‚ÄúAnd their influence is systematically lower. And they‚Äôre speaking less. And when they‚Äôre speaking up::: they‚Äôre not being listened to as much::: and they are being interrupted more.‚Äù

But there are changes we can make to help women speak up and be listened to more.

column3: Put your knowledge into practice::: continue preparing every day in what you are passionate about and will become essential for your company::: you will always have good opportunities for success ‚ù§Ô∏è
column4: Garrett James
column5: I graduated in the midst of the Great Recession. My first job was not what I expected and was not until a few months after graduation. Look for any opportunity to get in to your field. I started as a contractor through a temp agency as a chemist (degree in chemical engineering)::: a year later turned that in to a full time hire position (using my experience as a temp chemist to get a job as a full time engineer for the same process::: but on an industrial scale instead of a lab)::: and advanced steadily from there.
column6: The degree might get you the interview::: but your ability to solve someone's problems gets you hired.
column7:
From those of us who faced the Great Recession:
- Find out what needs to be done and become an expert in it.
- Make yourself invaluable to those in need of your expertise. Be willing to work harder and smarter than everyone else and be the one that gets the job done.
- Be willing to go down paths you didn‚Äôt plan on if that is where the need lies. Ex: my husband graduated in engineering and took a job in state corrections because that was what was hiring. He is now the payroll manager using skills he learned in his business classes.
- Be realistic about what you can tolerate on a day-to-day basis. Being stuck in a job that makes you miserable will hurt you and impair your ability to succeed. But also seize on your strengths and be willing to put in the hard work to advance. Ex: working in a call center was NOT for me! But working in the healthcare administration field fit my skills and talents quite well.

BYU psychology professor Julianne Holt-Lunstad is a world-renowned expert on the influence of social relationships on physical health::: with specific expertise in how loneliness impacts our wellbeing. While she‚Äôs concerned that this current pandemic we face can cause further social disconnection::: she‚Äôs also hopeful that through this we can see greater awareness of the importance of being socially connected. We can create positive changes and come together as communities. Watch as Julianne shares with us just how important even the perception of social support can be. In order to get through this together::: let‚Äôs be more socially connected than ever::: despite being physically distant.

#StayHome #StaySafe #StayConnected

NEWS.BYU.EDU
The Importance of Social Connectedness while Physical Distancing

Consistent with the CES guidelines issued last night::: BYU has made the following decisions.

Classes:

Classes on March 13::: 16 and 17 are cancelled. All courses at BYU::: including its Salt Lake Center::: will resume March 18 through remote instruction. Some courses cannot reasonably meet remotely::: such as lab courses or performance-based courses. College deans will communicate with departments about any specific exceptions.

Travel home:

BYU encourages students to consider leaving campus and returning home to finish Winter semester through remote coursework. We recognize individual circumstances may not allow this. Services and on-campus housing will continue to be available for those who choose to remain.

More information: byu.edu/coronavirus

BYU.EDU
Coronavirus (COVID-19) Updates

But if you look outside and it‚Äôs raining and you‚Äôre training for the Olympic trials::: then there‚Äôs a reason to go run." ‚Äî2016 Olympic marathoner Jared Ward

Cougar fans have several runners to cheer for this Saturday at the U.S. Olympic trials for the marathon::: including Ward and All-Americans Connor McMillan and Clayton Young::: who have trained together in Provo. Note: In the time period producing this film::: BYU student Conner Mantz sustained an injury and will not be competing at the trials.

In a new study::: researchers from BYU's public health department found that kids playing youth sports consume more calories in post-game snacks than they actually burn during their games.

NEWS.BYU.EDU
Study: Kids eat more calories in post-game snacks than they burn during the game

column15: After raising 4 kids I can tell you that kids do not needs snacks all the time. Everyone has gotten into the bad habit that when their kid is a bit hungry they need a snack. Reasons they don‚Äôt: 1) It is good for them to feel some hunger 2) it teaches patience 3) It teaches them to appreciate food when they get it. 4) It teaches them what kids throughout the world go through. Of course there are all kinds of exceptions to this and I certainly am not talking about starving your child but if they go hungry for 30 minutes that‚Äôs okay.
column16: I could have told you that without a study....
column17: Thank you. Many people on this thread must not realize the unhealthy habits we are teaching our kids with the usual snacks I‚Äôve seen served over and over after youth sports. This study is not about shaming kids for eating a snack::: it is teaching kids to have a good relationship with food and exercise. As a parent and a nurse::: I‚Äôve been horrified at the snacks offered my kids after youth sports. No one needs a bottle of Gatorade (full of sugar)::: Oreos::: or crackers and ‚Äúgummy fruit snacks‚Äù after a workout. I would try to bring water::: popcorn or fruit and I was the ‚Äúweird parent‚Äù. American culture needs to rethink what we are teaching our kids to eat. Childhood obesity is an epidemic.
column18:

Let‚Äôs not encourage food fear. It‚Äôs NEDA week. Check out some articles on Intuitive Eating instead!
column19: For my daughter's soccer there were half time snacks and after game snacks. We had no snacks growing up. Not sure how it's come to this.
column20: I‚Äôm a pediatric dentist and have coached many seasons of basketball::: soccer and flag football. I‚Äôm glad to see a study like this come out that supports what I‚Äôve been telling parents for a long time. Thank you!
column21:
It seems like a lot of the comments are focused on the idea of restrictive eating and calorie counting and how that's detrimental to an approach to food in one's life. But I think just as much of the article is focused on replacing empty calories with more nutrient dense foods. That is important::: and not a toxic mindset::: especially in the world of athletics.

It also isn't saying "never have snacks or sweet foods or enjoy higher-calorie treats." But to have baked goods and sugary drinks at every sports game isn't exactly helpful or doing the kids a favor.

Also::: it's soooo important to teach good habits to children when they are younger so they don't have to fight for years to undo them in the future. It's so much easier to maintain a healthy weight and healthy habits than to make big changes to your life to lose weight or alter eating habits.
column22: Because post game snacks used to be water and fruit and now they are Pinterest worthy robots built from granola bars::: Gatorade::: candy and junk. Water. The kids need water. Not a 20 ounce blue dyed Gatorade.
column23: Whatever happened to water and orange slices like when I was a kid? I got parents angry with me when I didn‚Äôt provide a junk bag full of tons of snacks after a soccer game for my kid.

column28:
I have a coworker who struggled with eating disorders for many years and she expresses to me a lot how difficult it is to live in this world that preaches CALORIES and BURNING off what you EAT and losing weight. It‚Äôs a very toxic mentality to limit yourself what you eat based off what you burn/don‚Äôt burn - teaching this to kids at such a young age is just awful. The term ‚Äúcalories‚Äù is very vague here in the title - could be coming from spinach for all we know (which is healthy::: yes?). So this study is a bit frustrating to me since it‚Äôs very triggering in the eating disorder umbrella. People need to give their bodies food. Kids need to give their bodies food. It‚Äôs essential to their mental and physical wellbeing. Some may say ‚Äúpeople are just too sensitive about this - it‚Äôs just a silly study‚Äù but... we are all neighbors here struggling/
dealing with something so let‚Äôs put ourselves in their shoes for a moment üíï

column38: Interesting that during National Eating Disorder Awareness Week this is the article you decide to share. This article is biased::: the study has a relatively small sample size and missing so many other factors. I would be skeptical taking this study to heart and seek other studies and sources that are unbiased and have better research protocols.

column41: Growing kids need activities they love but also calories. If they‚Äôre facing obesity::: that‚Äôs a different issue.
column42: I find it strange how many people are having issues with the study. Kids don't need that much sugar at all the different events they go too. Teaching them to eat healthy snacks instead of them learning to expect snacks that go over the daily recommended amount of sugar is a good thing. And sure::: kids are burning more calories throughout the day but I bet they are eating more sugar too.
column43: So NOT getting McDonald's after playing soccer will help me stay fit? I think we need more research into this.
column44: I can‚Äôt stand this trend of having to provide snack bags after the game. When I was a kid it was cut up orange quarters at half time. That‚Äôs it. Now everything has to be a big production.
column45: This is interesting research::: but I think you have to be careful with how you're framing it. A few thoughts: 1. While I agree children should choose healthier snacks (fruit::: as suggested in the article)::: post workout is the best time to replenish glycogen stores::: which can be accomplished with simple carbohydrates. 2. I think it's dangerous to get kids and parents thinking about trying to burn more calories in exercise than they consume afterward. That could be a recipe for disordered eating in the future. Young children shouldn't be playing soccer to lose weight. 3. I'd be more concerned about the kids who AREN'T in the game‚Äîwho might not be developing a healthy sense of enjoyment about physical activity.
column46: I'm still waiting for the study that shows that beards do not affect academic performance in any way.
column47: So...are they not going to move the rest of the day? Kids are amazing intuitive eaters if us adults got out of the way and stopped micromanaging their appetites. So they eat a bit more after the soccer game. They will likely account for that increase in energy intake later in the day by moving more or eating less. Let them be kids.

column61:
As a therapist who specializes in treating individuals with eating disorders/
disordered eating::: I find so many problems here (both in the study and in the article published by BYU)::: it‚Äôs hard to know where to begin. Here goes::: in no particular order:

1. Just to get this one out of the way: ‚ÄúKids are getting inundated with snack culture all the time.‚Äù Snack culture?? A culture in which children eat snacks? And that‚Äôs a bad thing?

2. The ‚Äúfinding‚Äù looking at calories burned vs. calories eaten. Focusing on this finding perpetuates a huge issue that really DOES have negative impacts on health: the idea that movement is about earning or compensating for food. This idea is disordered. Whether or not the study was specifically trying to say that kids should consume the exact number of calories they burned (or fewer) to be healthy::: the fact that the study was using this metric to draw conclusions about the health of youth in sports is problematic.

3. This quote: ‚ÄúSo many kids are at games just to get their treat afterwards::: which really isn‚Äôt helping to develop healthy habits long term:::‚Äù Spruance said. ‚ÄúThe reward should be::: ‚ÄòI got to have fun::: I got to run around with my friend or score a goal.‚Äô‚Äù More problems here. First of all::: vilifying eating for pleasure is a slippery slope into more disordered ideas. If having ‚Äútreats‚Äù becomes a bad thing::: we‚Äôre introducing shame into a perfectly normal part of eating. Shame about eating can lead to disordered eating. Eating can be fun::: can be social::: can be pleasurable::: and still be ‚Äúhealthy‚Äù because food is not JUST fuel::: and health is not just about food or weight. Food is fuel::: and the type of fuel we give our bodies does matter::: but we are also built to enjoy eating for many purposes::: not just to balance energy expenditure. Furthermore::: having food be a fun part of playing sports does not detract from the other rewards of sports::: as the author seems to imply in this quote.

4. The whole design of the study (as well as its sample size) is problematic if it is being used to create interventions or recommendations
for youth sports. The study essentially took a tiny snapshot of a child‚Äôs activity levels and eating::: and concluded that there was a problem because kids ate more than the recommended daily intake of sugar::: plus an ‚Äúextra‚Äù 43 calories. This type of fragmented view is also an example of a perspective that is edging on disordered. Our bodies are resilient and flexible when it comes to eating. As has been recommended::: please see the research on intuitive eating. The books Anti-Diet::: by Christy Harrison::: and Intuitive Eating::: by Evelyn Tribole and Elyse Resch::: are great starting points. If we look at ANY tiny snapshot of a day and try to compare calories burned vs. calories eaten as a marker of health::: we won‚Äôt get the full picture. There is nothing wrong with inviting parents to bring a greater variety of foods to the post-game snack::: but there IS a problem with fear-mongering about food based on findings from tiny moments in the lives of a tiny sample size of kids.

Vilifying sugar::: vilifying ‚Äútreats:::‚Äù vilifying snacks::: reducing food to output vs. intake::: focusing on calories in both eating and exercise::: fear-mongering about obesity‚Ä¶ SO many problems here::: and many of them in the realm of disordered eating.

The power of positivity.

BYU researchers in the BYU McKay School of Education spent three years observing elementary school teachers::: in 151 classrooms::: in three different states. They found by praising::: instead of reprimanding::: teachers saw up to a 30 percent increase in students‚Äô focus in the classroom.

Or in the words of the researchers::: the higher the teachers‚Äô praise-to-reprimand ratio::: the higher the students‚Äô on-task behavior percentage.

NEWS.BYU.EDU
Praising students in a classroom setting has big impact on their behavior

column16: I taught preschool for years. I had one class that fought constantly. A few kids were always excluded or bullied. I started doing a daily ‚Äúsunshine friend‚Äù. I would choose a different child every day. All the teachers and aides would watch that child and write down good things they witnessed. At the end of the day we would publicly recognize that child and all the good things we saw. Soon the kids were looking for good things in everyone. Instead of tattling they would tell the teachers when they saw good things. And they began to praise each other. At the end of the year we had an amazing class where the kids wanted to be together and to learn. They tried to do what was right and help each other. Best class ever!

column11: This is only an indirect correlation. People back in the 1900s were persuaded to buy 1% or 0% (skim) instead of 4% (whole) or 2%. Those same people were persuaded to stop buying nicotine::: caffeine::: and ethanol. They also exercised more::: lived in safer neighborhoods::: drove safer cars::: and could afford better healthcare. In the end::: they lived nine years longer. The professor notices a correlation where those who drank skim milk lived longer. He then credits the skim milk for the whole nine years. Meanwhile::: in this new century (already 20% past)::: we have learned that fat from food is useful for the human brain. The professor isn't getting any fat.
column12: From the abstract: ‚Äúwhen the sample was restricted to adults reporting only low saturated fat consumption (tertile 1)::: there was no relationship between milk fat intake and telomere length.‚Äù

column17: I'd advise those who are interested to find the original study and read it. News media tends to misreport or misinterpret study results. Even if the news report is portraying these study results accurately::: and even if the study is high quality and reliable-\-\one study doesn't mean much. Nutrition information given out by professionals is backed by hundreds of studies::: if not thousands. Now::: dietitians do advise people to select low-fat dairy instead of high-fat dairy. However::: common sense says that::: if you're eating a generally healthful diet and getting moderate exercise::: choosing to drink whole milk isn't going to shorten your lifespan or age you. Getting very little exercise and eating many unhealthy foods over many years will do those things-\-\but one single aspect of your diet isn't going to make or break you. My advise: Eat more fruit and vegetables::: get enough exercise::: and if you're passionate about whole milk (or skim milk::: or raw milk::: ect)-\-\you're gonna be fine.

Tucker says::: ‚ÄúMilk is probably the most controversial food in our country:::‚Äù ...Why? It's because of the dairy industry which is highly subsidized with a large lobbying sector. They prevent small local dairies from competing on both price and production...

When a new unique study goes against years and years of previous studies showing the exact opposite... It should be taken with a healthy dose of skepticism. At least::: until there are a number of other studies that can reproduce his results and confirm it...

Until then... I'm not buying it!

column64:
Bottom line: Whole milk for children::: low-fat milk for adults.

It looks like a careful study::: which is a statistical analysis of a sample of 5:::834 taken from the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey dataset::: for the years 1999-2002::: when the length of telomeres was analyzed.

(Telomeres are protective proteins added to the ends of DNA: they act to protect DNA::: in in a manner like shoelace aglets protect shoelaces from unraveling. As we age::: the telomeres get shorter and shorter. When cell division fails::: we die.)

If we can figure out how to stop telomeres from getting shorter::: we might be able to live forever. The immortal plenarian (flatworm) Schmidtea mediterranea suggests::: paradoxically::: that the best way to live forever is to starve!
https://
www.sciencedirec
t.com/science/
article/pii/
S221367111930231
0

One biochemical model cited in the study suggests a cause for the correlation: According to Bodo C. Melnik::: "Palmitic acid::: the primary saturated fatty acid of milk fat globules::: also activates mTORC1 at the lysosome. In short::: it appears that repeated mTORC1 activation contributes to endoplasmic reticulum stress::: leading to premature aging and disease."

Needless to say ... the past decade at BYU had A LOT.

From Old Spice parody and fictitious goaltender face trauma to Jimmermania and the Miracle at Memorial. From Vocal Point on The Sing Off to Cosmo and the Cougarettes going super viral. From #BYUHalloween to the Freshman Y. From No. 1 rankings to a new BYU president. From researching superhydrophic surfaces to Disney princesses to fireflies to helicopter parenting to bulletproof origami ... and a lot more.

See the full Decade in Review with links to full videos and content:

news.byu.edu/a-decade-in-review-at-byu

What were your favorite moments?

The road to adulthood‚Äîwhatever that means‚Äîhas never been longer. BYU researchers say a few things have changed dramatically in the last 25 years about how young people transition to adulthood. Today‚Äôs young adults are hitting traditional adult milestones (landing full-time jobs::: marrying::: having kids) later than any of their predecessors have.

Read more in the link below on what emerging adults can do to navigate this sometimes difficult period.

MAGAZINE.BYU.EDU
Why are young people struggling with adulthood?
column3: Look at the parents who raised them.
column4:
I think it's more apt to say that people "in Utah" may be having trouble hitting the "Utah adult milestones"::: namely getting married when you're 18 or 21::: having kids when you're 22::: and so forth. The rest of the world doesn't necessarily do things so quickly.

Here's the thing: not all of us wanted to "treat our 20's as an adult playland". I wanted to get married and have kids in my 20's. It was really frustrating to see everyone go on to this so called "adulthood". I didn't have my "career" until I was 31 when I became a Registered Nurse. I was trying to have a career doing other things but it wasn't panning out. But in my 30's::: I established a solid career::: found a great woman::: got married and started having kids. Now we also own a home.

But just because you are technically doing all the adult things now doesn't mean you can't do the things you loved as a kid. I still play guitar in a rock band.

Your life is YOUR life. It's not going to be the same as everyone else's. An adult is just a grown human. Just because you don't own a home or have kids or go to bed at 9 pm doesn't mean you are irresponsible or "not an adult".

Do what you want and life the life you want to. If you don't want to get married and have kids::: don't! It's a big sacrifice::: and you have to really want it.

Would I be sad if I didn't have my wife and kids? Yes::: it would be lonesome. But I hope I would look at the bright side of it all. I'd have more money and freedom to travel::: try different things::: move around.

Sometimes things work out to where you have the happy marriage::: kids::: house and all that. Sometimes it doesn't. I volunteered at a homeless shelter where I helped young families with 2-3 children::: just grateful to have a place to stay and some toast and coffee to eat for breakfast.

There is a good part of life that is beyond our control. Love and marriage don't always work out like we want them to. Maybe we need to be more willing to give people a chance. Maybe we have unrealistic expectations. Who knows? Just be honest with yourself::: what you want out of life::: and go get it.
column5:
Great ideas here. But I would also hope that the church (both the formal organization and the culture) would stop treating YSAs like kids. When I was in the RS president YSA ward at age 30::: we were required to have chaperones on an overnight temple trip to another city. When I asked if I could be on the of the chaperones::: I was told no::: *per the handbook*::: the chaperones had to be married people (and who ended up being younger than us...so basically sending the clear message that only married people were full adults who are able to control themselves.) I have many more examples like this from my experiences as a YSA all over the country.

If the church is serious about helping YSAs move into adulthood::: then there should be a greater effort especially in family wards to give YSAs greater responsibility by for example considering them for "big" callings and making sure their viewpoints and perspectives are considered and listened to. It can be very discouraging) and frankly alienating) to have responsibility and be trusted in worldly contexts like at work and then come to church and be told and treated as if you aren't a full adult and thus don't matter unless you get married.

The ease of the way. And I'm guilty of this. Carving out a life and carving out of yourself a better person is no job for wimps. But why do it when you don't have to?

We are blessed beyond measure. The common person has access to better food::: better transportation:::
finer things than all the kings of the earth up until the last century. Adulthood is a call to responsibility and its hard to not expect the world for doing nothing when that is how so many of us came into this life.

Props to every parent who makes work vital in all they are teaching their kids.

column17:
I wish anthropologists
could be more valuable to these kinds of researches. This is not just a psychological or sociological change::: it is cultural. Culture needs to be understood in all aspects of life to be able to understand this topic. What it means to be an adult? How adulthood was seen in the past? How it is seen today? The article kind of states that adulthood means to have a full time job::: married and kids. It is just a way of seeing things based on perspectives from the past. I think there is too much pressure on young adults. That‚Äôs the problem. In the past they had just one vision of things: life was to get married::: have kids and work. But now this globalized and multiculturalis
m world changes the way things are seen. So the transitions need to be well understood::: but again::: culture needs to be understood too. If you would ask me what adulthood is I would probably say: be responsible for your own actions::: put priorities first::: sacrifice your time::: money and talents in behalf of others::: make clear and reasonable decisions::: live a life to meet your professional goals (I would never say in order to be an adult have kids). So many different subcultures::: that‚Äôs why it is very complex to generalize a result. I am 29 years old::: 2 kids::: and sometimes I don‚Äôt feel I am a complete adult like my parents and their friends used to be in the past. So. ü§∑üèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è
column19: I know for me::: it took a bit longer because of the push to finish my education and start a career. We got married after we both graduated and in the 6 years we have been married::: we have had to live with my spouse's parents twice. Housing costs way more than it used to::: higher education too. Plus having a healthy pregnancy and uncomplicated unmedicated birth for both my girls cost us a combined $7:::000 with insurance! Almost double what the insurance had told us. I don't know if we will have any more kids just based on the cost. In the neighborhood we live in::: it cost $80:::000 to build a home here in 1991. Houses are now being sold for almost $300:::000 for a home that is considered a first family home. School in my parents time could be paid by working in the summer. I worked the entire time just to pay rent::: car insurance::: and phone with not much left over besides a plane home for the holidays. Plus when my parents had kids::: I cost them a total of $100. So yes::: we waited because everything costs a ton. I recently tried going back to work::: but it wouldn't have been worth it because I'd be paying most of my paycheck to a babysitter. *Sigh*
column20: Thanks Larry Nelson. Means more to me now that I've got teenagers. Finances are a huge part of this as you say. Also::: that dynamic where parents now try to delay their kids on marriage feels like a complete reversal from how things used to work.

Walt Disney Studios ‚Äì the division of Disney that oversees live-action films ‚Äì recently announced that 40 percent of their upcoming directors are women. They also make more movies starring a female character than those that don‚Äôt.
